Instrument Description ====================== ASAS is an airborne imaging spectroradiometer employing a silicon charge injection device (cid) detector array operated in the push broom mode. It acquires digital image data for 29 spectral bands in the visible and near infrared portion of the spectrum, with a spectral resolution of 15 nm. The field of view can be pointed up to 45 degrees off nadir, either fore or aft of the platform aircraft. The instrument is typically used to track a target site through 7 discrete view directions as the instrument flies over the site.
The signals generated by the detector array are amplified, digitized, and stored in digital form. The rate at which the electronics scan the signals from element rows (i.e., the frame rate) can be adjusted to 3, 6, 12, 24, 48, and 64 frames per second. Only 48 and 64 were used in GRSFE. Increasing the frame rate decreases the radiometric response of the elements. Following signal read out and amplification, the signals are digitized to 12 bit words and then stored in a pulse code modulated format by an on-board high bit rate tape recorder. The data rate varies depending on the frame rate.
ASAS uses an f/1.4 objective lens with a 57.2 mm focal length, providing a 25 degree field of view. The lens focuses incoming energy through an entrance slit into a 1:1 relay with an effective focal length of 76.3 mm in each half of the relay. A 90 degree mirror prism in each half of the relay folds the optical path to create a compact optical head. A transmission grating ruled at 75 lines/mm and blazed at 530 nm is located between the two prisms to disperse the radiant energy into a spectrum. The second prism directs the dispersed energy onto the focal plane.
Science Objectives ================== The main objective for ASAS observations was to measure spectral radiance of surfaces at different times of day from multiple view directions.
Operational Considerations ========================== A neutral density filter was used during the GRSFE project because of the high reflectance of Lunar Lake.
Calibration Description ======================= Spectral and radiometric calibrations are based on laboratory reference sources. A monochromometer was used to determine spectral band location and shape. The reference source for radiometric responsivity is a 1.2 meter diameter integrating hemisphere. Both sources are operated using the standards and calibration office of NASA/GSFC. The intent of the calibration is to be able to transform raw digital counts to units of radiance.
